profile_template: {{Name}} can always get the class cackling with {{his}} running commentary, but especially when {{he}} starts doing impersonations. Somehow {{he}}'s able to do it in a way that everyone can laugh at it.
argument_1: You'll have so many career opportunities - high income, job flexibility, lots of options.
argument_2: Computer science is pervasive in every field. No matter what you plan to do when you finish school, knowing something about computer science will help you be better at your job.
argument_3: It looks really good on your resume to take a computer science class, because it tells employers that you’re knowledgeable about a topic that’s really important.
argument_4: You can take AP computer science classes and get college credit before even going to college.  It'll save money on tuition when you're in college as well.
argument_5: Knowing the basics of CS can help you find ways to work more efficiently, even if you’re not working directly in CS. You can use your CS skills to do your job quicker and better.
argument_6: Computer science creates so many new ways to express your creativity, whether it's generating images or videos,  creating interactive stories, or making new kinds of media altogether.
argument_7: There are even a lot of artists now that use CS to create their work (composition, 3D modeling, design).
argument_8: People in the arts and architecture rely on design software all the time.
argument_9: Computing is part of designing new products, not just technical ones.  This isn't just gadgets and apps either, there are even wearable computers now.
argument_10: Computing is a big part of visualization and imagery. You’ve seen computer-generated graphics in movies and video games. It’s useful in science, too, to picture a problem or process.
argument_11: Computing is ubiquitous. Learning about computer science will help you understand the world around you.
argument_12: Computer science jobs are high-paying and high status, and can empower you to push back against current forms of oppression.
argument_13: There are real cultural and structural barriers that might make it hard to pursue computer science at the college level.  Getting started now in high school will be easier.
argument_14: Learning CS can help you connect or build global communities that share your interests and passions.
argument_15: Since computing can be an applied science, it underpins innovations across whole fields. If you were interested in medicine for example, you could be part of a new innovation in health care.
argument_16: You might be surprised to know only half of computing jobs are in high tech companies! You could mash up your interests in other careers with technology and work anywhere
argument_17: Computing connects people to businesses and to information and to each other too.
argument_18: Understanding computer science will help you understand and be engaged in some of the major ethical and civic issues of our time.
argument_19: Lots of people work to keep computers safe from hackers. People also use computers to solve crimes.

argument_1: You'll have so many career opportunities - high income, job flexibility, lots of options.
argument_2: Computer science is pervasive in every field. No matter what you plan to do when you finish school, knowing something about computer science will help you be better at your job.
argument_3: It looks really good on your resume to take a computer science class, because it tells employers that you’re knowledgeable about a topic that’s really important.
argument_4: You can take AP computer science classes and get college credit before even going to college.  It'll save money on tuition when you're in college as well.
argument_5: Knowing the basics of CS can help you find ways to work more efficiently, even if you’re not working directly in CS. You can use your CS skills to do your job quicker and better.
argument_6: Computer science creates so many new ways to express your creativity, whether it's generating images or videos,  creating interactive stories, or making new kinds of media altogether.
argument_7: There are even a lot of artists now that use CS to create their work (composition, 3D modeling, design).
argument_8: People in the arts and architecture rely on design software all the time.
argument_9: Computing is part of designing new products, not just technical ones.  This isn't just gadgets and apps either, there are even wearable computers now.
argument_10: Computing is a big part of visualization and imagery. You’ve seen computer-generated graphics in movies and video games. It’s useful in science, too, to picture a problem or process.
argument_11: Computing is ubiquitous. Learning about computer science will help you understand the world around you.
argument_12: Computer science jobs are high-paying and high status, and can empower you to push back against current forms of oppression.
argument_13: There are real cultural and structural barriers that might make it hard to pursue computer science at the college level.  Getting started now in high school will be easier.
argument_14: Learning CS can help you connect or build global communities that share your interests and passions.
argument_15: Since computing can be an applied science, it underpins innovations across whole fields. If you were interested in medicine for example, you could be part of a new innovation in health care.
argument_16: You might be surprised to know only half of computing jobs are in high tech companies! You could mash up your interests in other careers with technology and work anywhere
argument_17: Computing connects people to businesses and to information and to each other too.
argument_18: Understanding computer science will help you understand and be engaged in some of the major ethical and civic issues of our time.
argument_19: Lots of people work to keep computers safe from hackers. People also use computers to solve crimes.
